projects.title: Tracing the Enduring Effects of Community Arts Programs (TEECAP)
projects.abstract: <strong>Funded by the Wallace Foundation. The TEECAP project gathers and analyzes extensive life history interviews with former participants of community arts out-of-school programs to gain insight into how participation in such programs influenced participants’ understanding of the value of informal arts learning over the life course...

projects.title: Connected Arts Learning
projects.abstract:
Funded by the Wallace Foundation.
The connected arts learning project calls attention to how community arts programs intentionally foster not only youth achievements within the arts or academics, but also youth and community thriving—through outcomes such as youth civic engagement, occupational identities, and wellness...

projects.title: STEAM as a Means for Educational Equity
projects.abstract:
Funded by The National Science Foundation (#1647150) and Wellcome Trust
As part of the broader Science Learning+ project Creativity and Equity in STEM Learning, this project explores how does the materiality of tools and materials shape learning in arts-and-science experiences...

projects.title: Designing a New Nexus
projects.abstract:
Funded by The National Science Foundation (IIS #1553398)
Extending earlier work on computational textiles (e-textiles) through systematic comparisons across a variety of new tools, materials, and practices used in electronics and computing, this project more fully theorizes how the social construction of various tools and materials shapes learning and participation...

projects.title: Chicago Arts Partnerships in Education (CAPE)
projects.abstract:
Funded by Chicago Arts Education Partnerships and 21st Century Community Learning Centers
This project, (Re)constructing learning spaces for inquiry, community, and openness, funded by a 21st Century Community Learning Center grant, builds from a core Creativity Labs’ focus on the value of arts education and learning...

projects.title: Re-Crafting Mathematics Education
projects.abstract:
Funded by The National Science Foundation (DRL #1420303)
his collaborative project, titled ‘Re-Crafting Mathematics Education: Designing Tangible Manipulatives Rooted in Traditional Female Crafts,’ is based on our prior work studying design, mathematics, and traditional female crafts, particularly when integrated with electronics (i.e., e-textiles)....

projects.title: Computational Textiles as Materials for Creativity
projects.abstract:
Funded by The National Science Foundation (IIS-0855886)
This project explored how to encourage youth (ages 10 to 18) to contribute in meaningful ways to the emergent field of computational textile design....

projects.title: Interest-Driven Arts Learning
projects.abstract:
Funded by the Wallace Foundation
This project examined the influence and potential impact of new technologies for arts learning to help us understand and validate today’s wide range of arts learning experiences, conceptualize learning in the arts during the out-of-school hours, and suggest strategies for how we might support and sustain interest-driven arts learning in a digital age...

projects.title: Learning and Achieving Through the Arts (LATA)
projects.abstract:
Funded by the US Department of Education
The Learning and Achieving Through the Arts (LATA) program provided arts education to youth (grades K through 6) who were facing barriers to succeed in school that stem from poverty, homelessness, and limited English-language proficiency...

projects.title: Rhythmic Games and Digital Composition
projects.abstract:
Funded by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation
Our research—spanning youth, rock musicians, professional gamers with no musical experience, music educators, and professional classical musicians—sought to understand more deeply how rhythmic action games and the tools and representations of these types of games further mediate preparation and participation in more formal music context. ...

projects.title: ReCrafting Computer Science
projects.abstract:
Funded by the National Science Foundatation (ECR-EHR-2100401).
This project theorizes that activities that place computational thinking within a broader socio-technical context will not only broaden participation and collaboration in computer science, but also expand definitions of what counts as valuable learning in CS education...

projects.title: Connected Learning in Libraries
projects.abstract:
Funded by the City of Santa Ana.
This project aims build capacity among librarians and library staff around interest driven learning in libraries...

projects.title: Encouraging Wonderment via Summer STEAM
projects.abstract:
Funded by Design, Make, Learn and in partnership with the Long Beach Unified School District.
This research and evaluation partnership centers on design thinking and making in out-of-school learning...

projects.title: How Narrative Elements Shape Girls' Engagement in Engineering
projects.abstract:
Funded by The National Science Foundation (DRL #1712803)
This project systematically investigated whether and how narrative elements of engineering design activities can influence engagement with those activities. The goal was to build evidence-based guidance for exhibit and program development and for facilitation of engineering design activities that can provide equitable, effective engineering design experiences for girls...

projects.title: Maker Ed Open Portfolio Project
projects.abstract:
Funded by The Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation
The Open Portfolio Project aimed to develop technology solutions and a common set of practices for portfolio creation, reflection, sharing, and assessment. Through our investigations we developed a guiding philosophy of what constitutes an open and decentralized lifetime portfolio system for makers....

projects.title: BioSim
projects.abstract:
Funded by The National Science Foundation (IIS #1324047)
BioSim, a participatory simulation where young students (grades K-3) enact the roles of honeybee and army ants in biological systems through the assistance of computer-enhanced e-puppets, is designed to elevate youths’ understanding of complex systems though novel combinations of play, reflection, interaction, and exploration...

projects.title: A Systems Approach to Curriculum for Schools and After-School Spaces
projects.abstract:
Funded by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation
Interconnections: Understanding Systems through Digital Designs, is a curriculum designed for school and non-school use and builds on the existing work of educators, management theorists, designers, and learning scientists who are aiming to promote systems thinking in young people...

projects.title: Make-to-Learn
projects.abstract:
Funded by the Digital Media and Learning Hub at the University of Irvine and the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation
Make-to-Learn is an effort that leverages DIY culture, digital practices, and educational research to advocate for placing making, creating, and designing at the core of educational practice...

projects.title: Scratch for Media Art Making
projects.abstract:
Funded by The National Science Foundation (IIS #0325828) and Spencer Foundation
Peppler’s dissertation work draws upon the emerging professional field of “media arts” and the ways that youth use Scratch and other new technologies for communication as a way to design a 21st century K-12 arts education curriculum...

projects.title: Making Connections for the Million Girl Moonshot
projects.abstract:
Funded by STEM Next Opportunity Fund and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation.
Through research with partners on the national, state, and local program levels, this project leverages the connected learning framework to study the strategies STEM programs create to support middle school girls through transitions from one out-of-school STEM program to another...

projects.title: Intelligent Immersive Environments for Learning Robotics
projects.abstract:
Funded by the National Science Foundation (#2202611).
This research and development effort is creating immersive and responsive environments for robotics instruction...

projects.title: Exploring Tacit Knowledge with AI and XR
projects.abstract:
Funded by the National Science Foundation.
This project deepens the fundamental understanding of tacit knowledge through a mixed-method research framework to clear a pathway to develop a feasible solution to train future machinists and understand the acquisition and transmission of tacit knowledge in workplace settings...

projects.title: Advancing Data Visualization Literacy in Museums
projects.abstract:
Funded by The National Science Foundation (DRL #1713567)
This innovations in Development AISL project is motivated by the insight that in the information age, being able to 'read and write' data visualizations is becoming as important as being able to read and write text..

projects.title: Designing Future Factory Human-Robot Workflows
projects.abstract:
Funded by the National Science Foundation (DUE-1931227).
This project explores how to understand and design human-robot workflows for the future using a physical simulation platform...

projects.title: AI For Classroom Orchestration
projects.abstract:
Funded by Digital Promise.
This project advanced a Research-Practice-Industry Partnership (RPIP) model for the development of AI that can be introduced into classrooms in ways that augment teaching and learning...

projects.title: Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier
projects.abstract:
Funded by The National Science Foundation (DUE #1839896)
Our project takes a multidisciplinary approach to address new technologies for more effective collaboration between workers, robotics, IoT, and AI into the product lifecycle, as well as the ramifications that this shift has on education systems and labor economics...

projects.title: Skill-LeARn: Augmented Reality Platform for Scaling Workforce Training
projects.abstract:
Funded by The National Science Foundation (OIA #1937036)
Through the lens of learning sciences, we aim to create and improve current approaches to pre-skill a new generation of workers as well as refine our approach for industry re-skilling efforts in the future of work...

projects.title: Workforce Upskilling via Online Learning
projects.abstract:
Funded by The Boeing Company
The goal of this research is to understand how to design online professional engineering courses to be more efficient for learners and make inferences about what participants are actually learning...

projects.title: Creative Economy at Inner-City Arts
projects.abstract:
Funded by the Donald Bren School of ICS Dean’s Office and Department of Informatics
This project examines how the arts can equip youth with foundational skills to enter and thrive in the creative economy of Southern California and how personalized learning pathways can build youth’s social networks and prepare them for the future of work....

projects.title: LRNG: Join the Evolution of Learning
projects.abstract:
Funded by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, Best Buy Foundation, and Fossil Foundation
LRNG is a movement that closes the opportunity gap and transforms how young people access and experience learning and the paths they can take to success...

projects.title: Hive Research Lab
projects.abstract:
Funded by the Spencer Foundation, John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, and New York Community Trust
Hive Research Lab was a research-practice partnership led by Indiana University and New York University that studied and collaborated with the Mozilla Hive NYC Learning Network. Its research and collaborations with Hive NYC members produced insights around participatory knowledge building methodologies, the affordances of “Working Open” in a distributed network, and the importance of brokering learning opportunities as a way to support youth pathways....

team.name: Dr. Kylie A. Peppler
team.title: Lab Director
team.intro: Kylie is a Professor in Informatics and Education at University of California, Irvine and Director of the Creativity Labs. An artist by training, she engages in research that focuses on the intersection of the arts, computational technologies, and informal learning.

team.name: Julie Herrick
team.title: Head of Operations
team.intro: Julie Herrick joined the CLL team in 2018 as the program administrator. In July of 2020 Julie became the head of operations for the CLL.She brings nearly two decades of experience in nonprofit administration and event planning. She holds a bachelor’s degree in organizational leadership from Chapman University.

team.name: Jenna Abrams
team.title: Program Administrator
team.intro: Jenna Abrams is a Program Administrator at the Connected Learning Lab, where she assists administratively on CLL research projects alongside managing the CLA newsletter and blog. She holds an MFA in Writing from UC Irvine.

team.name: Maggie Dahn
team.title: Associate Project Scientist
team.intro: Maggie Dahn is a postdoctoral scholar working with the Creativity Labs at University of California, Irvine. She received her Ph.D. in Education from UCLA. As a former teacher, her research interests include the design of learning environments and the development of voice and identity through art making.

team.name: Seth Corrigan
team.title: R&D Scientist
team.intro: Seth Corrigan is a research scientist working with the Creativity Labs at University of California, Irvine. He specializes in the use of quantitative methods with a focus on measurement, psychometrics and machine learning to develop novel learning and assessment technologies.

team.name: Joey Huang
team.title: Postdoctoral researcher
team.intro: She received her Ph.D. in Learning and Developmental Sciences from Indiana University Bloomington. Coming from educational psychology and computing, her research focuses on computational thinking, collaboration, and STEM learning. As a learning scientist by training, she aims to create more interesting and inspiring learning environments to promote equity and collaboration.

team.name: Aakriti Bisht
team.title: Graduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Aakriti is a Ph.D student in Education with a background in Science, Arts and Education. Prior to joining the program she was working on community based education programs in India which motivated her research interest around the importance of out-of-school learning spaces and the role of community in it.

team.name: Zhenyao Cai
team.title: Graduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Zhenyao Cai is a first-year Ph.D. student in Education. Her previous research projects involved tech-enhanced collaborative learning, AI literacy, maker education, and AR and embodied learning. In the long term, she wants to design and build technologies that involve participants in STEM learning at scale, and to investigate how the interactions that these technologies afford can shape and transform learners’ cognitive and affective capabilities.

team.name: Lora Cawelti
team.title: Graduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Lora Cawelti is a Ph.D. student in Education with a background in performing arts, teaching artistry, and arts programming in schools and community spaces. She is focused on understanding unique arts learning pathways and designing for arts learning that is rooted in inclusive, culturally sustaining pedagogies. Lora is interested in community engaged research practices and research practice partnerships.

team.name: Phebe Chew
team.title: Graduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Phebe Chew is a Ph.D. student in Education. She is interested in sociocultural perspectives around learning in out-of-school spaces, with special interest around how identity and relationships shape learning in the culinary arts and food media. She has experience in community-based research, ethnographic approaches, life history approaches, and participatory design.

team.name: Ariel Han
team.title: Graduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Ariel is a 4th year Ph.D. candidate in the informatics department at UC Irvine. Her research interests focuses on the intersection of educational technology, Artificial Intelligent and HCI. Based on a broad topic of HCI, she investigates fundamental questions on how people interact and collaborate with AI-powered creativity tools for their creative expression.

team.name: Shenshen Han
team.title: Graduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Shenshen is currently working as system/software specialist at Creativity Labs. His recent interest mainly lies on exploring the sense of the next generation Internet Computing. He is an enthusiast of computer networks and pervasive computing.

team.name: Santiago Ojeda-Ramirez
team.title: Graduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Santiago Ojeda-Ramirez is a Ph.D. student in Education. His background spans fields as engineering, literature and digital humanities. He is interested in sociocultural perspectives around STEAM education and more specifically Computer Science Education. He is also interested in Computational and Ai Literacies in intersection with Latine and Hispanic Culture. He has experience using both quantitative and qualitative methods and community-based research.

team.name: Mishael Sedas
team.title: Graduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Mishael is a doctoral student in education with a background in engineering. He is interested in using design to encourage and support interest-driven STEAM learning for non-dominant and low-income populations.

team.name: Seth Van Doren
team.title: Graduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Seth is a PhD student in Education interested in designing STEM learning experiences using participatory design research methods that center the values, desires, and aspirations of the groups that will engage with them. His experiences conducting design-based research and engaging in co-design with youth, informal science educators, science content experts, and researchers have shaped his current research interests.

team.name: Nikki Yankova
team.title: Graduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Nikki is a Ph.D student in Education with a background in math, English literature, and creative writing. She is interested in developing tools to facilitate learning and creative thought to promote mathematical thinking and broadening participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields.

team.name: Ulia Zaman
team.title: Undergraduate Student Researcher
team.intro: Ulia Zaman is a undergraduate Computer Science student. She has a passion for software programming and is interested in exploring the possibilities of AI in our daily lives.

news.title: StoryAI advanced in NSF-sponsored VITAL Prize Challenge Semi-Final Round
news.subTitle: Jul 2023
news.text: "Fourth-year informatics Ph.D. student Ariel Han, is exploring how to leverage generative artificial intelligence (AI) for culturally responsive learning. In particular, Han and Professor Peppler are working with a team of CreativityLabs researchers to design a web-based platform for AI-supported storytelling. Their AIStory project, which has received recent support from the National Science Foundation (NSF) and funding from UCI Beall Applied Innovation, offers personalized, interest-driven learning for elementary school students to enhance their literacy and storytelling skills in an inclusive environment."

news.title: The Connected Arts Learning Framework: An Expanded View of the Purposes and Possibilities for Arts Learning
news.subTitle: Mar 2023
news.text: "This report offers a framework for arts learning that connects the arts to children’s community, civic, and future professional life."

news.text: "Dr. Peppler speaks at SXSW EDU 2023 on research storytelling for the digital age"

news.subTitle: Jun 2022
news.text: "Creativity Labs research is featured in an article on how the application of artificial intelligence will have a major impact on the world of education and learning"

news.title: Faculty researchers secure another workforce development grant to support growth of machinists in manufacturing
news.subTitle: Oct 2022
news.text: "Creativity Labs teams up with the Rochester Institute of Technology to develop a system that improves passage of tacit knowledge from skilled machinists to those coming into the field."

news.title: Connected Learning Alliance: Performing Mathematics Through Crafting
news.subTitle: Nov 2022
news.text: "At the 2022 Connected Learning Summit, we had the opportunity to facilitate two math-crafts activities with conference attendees during our workshop “Creating A Doll Skirt Or A Basket: Performing Proportional Reasoning And Spatial Visualizations”."

news.title: NSF announces awards to shape the human-technology partnership for the well-being of workers and their productivity
news.subTitle: Nov 2018
news.text: The Creativity Labs is part of a National Science Foundation $25 million investment to advance the cognitive and physical capabilities of workers in the context of human-technology interactions.

news.title: Why Makerspaces are the key to innovation
news.subTitle: Jan 2018
news.text: Edvocate features the work of the Creativity Labs that describes why makerspaces are a key to innovation and an ideal method for equipping students to succeed in the future.
